body: An algorithm that prioritizes (gives privileges) small guilds to stay on the front page compared to larger guilds.

author.bio: I like big brains and I cannot lie.
author.bio_html: I like big brains and I cannot lie.

body:
Any chance you might tweak the weight of “newness”? Or maybe it’s more the rate that older posts fall off. 

It seems like older posts stay on a bit too long.

body: It's hard to grow guilds as it is, and this will make it even harder. It could get to the point where the whole site is controlled by an oligopoly of popular guilds like on reddit if you give an advantage to the popular guilds, when they already have the advantage of more subscribers. Unless the small guilds were actually given *more* weight before, but I've never heard of a site doing that.
body_html: It's hard to grow guilds as it is, and this will make it even harder. It could get to the point where the whole site is controlled by an oligopoly of popular guilds like on reddit if you give an advantage to the popular guilds, when they already have the advantage of more subscribers. Unless the small guilds were actually given more weight before, but I've never heard of a site doing that.

body:
> Unless the small guilds were actually given more weight before, but I've never heard of a site doing that.

The post title and content states it pretty clearly, it did and it still does to a lesser degree. Although I admit its news to me too.

Not sure how I feel about it; hot is for content that's already popular, so if its really advertising guilds that *need* the attention, then its not really what's hot and trending. If a guild's post *is* actually hot or trending and belongs, then it doesn't really need the extra advertising so much.
body_html:
Unless the small guilds were actually given more weight before, but I've never heard of a site doing that.

The post title and content states it pretty clearly, it did and it still does to a lesser degree. Although I admit its news to me too.

body: What you're forgetting is that posts usually start within their own guild's hot page, and *then* reach the overall hot page. So if a post in a small guild has less votes than one in a larger guild, but is more well liked proportionately to how many members the guild has, it should still outrank it.
body_html: What you're forgetting is that posts usually start within their own guild's hot page, and then reach the overall hot page. So if a post in a small guild has less votes than one in a larger guild, but is more well liked proportionately to how many members the guild has, it should still outrank it.
